Examples

This page contains code examples and snippets. Actually reading the material instead of just skimming, then copy and pasting is strongly recommended.

NZXTSharp's syntax is designed to be simple, easy to use, and easy to learn. The structure is built around the concepts of devices, subdevices, effects, and params.

Effects are created with params, and effects are applied to devices. Devices can "own" subdevices.

An example of a device would be a Hue+, and subdevices for the Hue+ might be an AER fan or RGB strip.

Getting Started

NZXTSharp can be used in one of two ways:
  • With the DeviceLoader class.
  • With individual device classes.

    • The DeviceLoader class provides a convenient interface for loading, and interacting with NZXT devices.

    The DeviceLoader

    The DeviceLoader can be instantiated, and has some static methods in case you don't want to deal with an instance.

    A loader instance can be created with a DeviceLoadFilter. Whatever category the filter defines, will be the devices that will be returned.

    To get started: 
        using NZXTSharp;

    DeviceLoader loader = new DeviceLoader();
    You can then apply RGB effects, and set fan/ pump speeds on devices owned by the loader instance. The loader class also exposes some useful methods for accessing, adding, removing, and filtering devices owned by the instace.

    You can also get devices of a specific type that are owned by the loader instance. For example, if the loader instance owns a HuePlus instance, it can be accessed by getting the DeviceLoader.HuePlus property.

    Then, using the NZXTSharp.HuePlus namespace, you can get full Hue+ functionality with the returned HuePlus instance.

    Individual Classes

    For examples on how to interact with individual classes, see the device specific docs below.

    Hue+

    The Hue+ model consists of the HuePlus class instance. The instance owns three HuePlusChannel objects, but only Channel1 and Channel2 objects have subdevices because they are the only "real" channels.

    Boilerplate

    To get started, you will need the following: 
        using NZXTSharp;
    using NZXTSharp.HuePlus;

    HuePlus hue = new HuePlus();
    With this HuePlus instance, you can apply effects, get channel info, toggle the unit LED, etc.

    Applying Effects

    Effects are applied to a Hue+ device with the ApplyEffect() method. The channel(s) to apply the effect to, and the effect object are passed as params to this method.

    Adding on to the last example: 
        using NZXTSharp;
    using NZXTSharp.HuePlus;

    HuePlus hue = new HuePlus();
    
    Color color = new Color(255, 255, 255); // You can make colors with RGB values
    Color color = new Color("#ffffff") // Also works with Hex codes(with or without leading #)
    
    Fixed effect = new Fixed(color) // Create effect
    
    hue.ApplyEffect(hue.Both, effect); // Apply effect to both channels
    hue.AppleEffect(hue.Channel1, effect); // Or just one
    
    hue.UnitLedOff(): // Turn unit LED off
    hue.UnitLedOn(); // And back on again!

    SubDevices

    A HuePlus instance has two channels that own subdevices: Channel1 and Channel2. The Both channel does not own any because it is not a "physical" channel. Keep in mind that ALL changes to subdevices need to be "pushed" to the deivce by setting, or re-setting an effect.

    All subdevice classes are held in the NZXTSharp namespace.

    Building on the Boilerplate example: 
        using NZXTSharp;
    using NZXTSharp.HuePlus;

    HuePlus hue = new HuePlus();
    Fixed effect = new Fixed(new Color("#FFFFFF");
    
    List Ch1Devices = hue.Channel1.SubDevices; // Not necessary, but syntax looks better
    Ch1Devices[0].AllLedOff(); // Turn off all LEDs on first subdevice in channel.
    hue.ApplyEffect(hue.Channel1, effect); // Apply changes
    
    Ch1Devices[1].ToggleLed(9); // Toggle individual LEDs with the ToggleLed method
    Ch1Devices[1].Leds[8] = false; // Or by setting the value
    hue.ApplyEffect(hue.Channel1, effect); // Apply changes
    
    Ch1Devices[1].ToggleLedRange(1, 5); // Or, toggle ranges of LEDs
    hue.ApplyEffect(hue.Channel1, effect); // Apply changes

    Custom RGB Values for a Fixed Effect

    The fixed effect, being the most versatile, allows the user of NZXTSharp to construct a fixed effect with custom RGB values for each LED. This is done by passing a byte array to a Fixed effect constructor.

    Byte array schema: The byte array must have at least one RGB value, and at most 120 RGB values. If the length is not within this range, an InvalidParamException will be thrown.

    RGB Value formatting: For the effect to display properly, all RGB values MUST be passed in G, R, B format. RGB values, like all other RGB values in NZXTSharp must be between 0-255 (inclusive).

    Building on the boilerplate example: 
        using NZXTSharp;
    using NZXTSharp.HuePlus;

    HuePlus hue = new HuePlus();
    
    // Create GRB array, this will have two LEDs lit: one white, one red.
    byte[] colors = new byte[] { 255, 255, 255, 0, 255, 0 };
    Fixed effect = new Fixed(colors); // Create Effect
                
    hue.ApplyEffect(hue.Both, effect); // And apply it!
                
    // Also supports subdevice and LED toggling.
    hue.Channe1.SubDevices[1].ToggleState(); // Toggle Device
    hue.ApplyEffect(hue.Both, effect); // Apply Changes
